questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infection. Physical examination shows height for age < -2 SD. What is the appropriate term for the above mentioned condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stunting

 

This is the correct answer. Stunting refers to impaired growth in height for age. If a child's height falls below -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median on growth charts, it indicates chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wasting: Wasting refers to low weight for height and is an indicator of acute malnutrition. It is assessed by comparing a child's weight to a reference standard for their height.

 

Option C. Severe Acute Malnutrition: While this term is related to malnutrition, it specifically refers to a combination of wasting and other clinical signs. Stunting alone does not categorize a child as having severe acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. Kwashiorkor: Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by protein deficiency. It often presents with edema, skin changes, and hepatomegaly. Stunting, as described in the scenario, is not a characteristic feature of kwashiorkor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the different indicators of malnutrition, specifically recognizing that height for age < -2 SD is a sign of stunting, which reflects chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with the defect seen in the image below. Identify the condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

 

Omphalocele is characterized by the presence of a sac enclosing the protruding abdominal organs, which herniate into the base of the umbilical cord.

 

The image depicts a newborn with a congenital abdominal wall defect characterized by the protrusion of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes. This condition is known as an omphalocele.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the intestines protrude through a hole in the abdominal wall, typically to the right of the umbilicus. Unlike omphalocele, in gastroschisis, the intestines are not covered by a sac and are exposed directly to the amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: Persistent vitellointestinal duct refers to a remnant of the yolk stalk (vitelline duct) that can cause various intestinal anomalies but does not present as a protrusion of abdominal contents covered by a sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polio

 

While infants can acquire polio antibodies from their mothers, this immunity is not consistent and can fade during infancy. Therefore, newborns are given a 0 dose of polio drops to ensure protection against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Maternal antibodies against tetanus can provide significant immunity to the newborn. Pregnant women are advised to receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, ideally between 27-36 weeks of gestation. Maternal antibodies produced from the vaccine can protect the newborn against tetanus.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Maternal antibodies provide some protection, but it's less reliable than tetanus


Protection duration is shorter (1-2 months)

 

Option D. Measles: Maternal antibodies help protect the baby from measles until about 9 months of age. After that, the efficacy of maternal antibodies decreases, which is why the measles vaccine is given at 9 months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with edema for last few months. It started on face but now it is generalized with pedal edema and ascites. He showed good response to steroids. His was RBS 112 mg/dl. On urine examination massive proteinuria was seen. On light microscopy the findings were unremarkable, on electron microscopy of kidney biopsy, effacement of podocytes was seen. Identify the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimal change disease

    

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is another cause of nephrotic syndrome but is less common in children than MCD. It typically shows segmental sclerosis on light microscopy, which was not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Membranous glomerulonephritis: This condition usually presents with subepithelial deposits and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy, which is not described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with hematuria, hypertension, and low complement levels, along with a history of recent streptococcal infection. It is not associated with the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Minimal Change Disease is characterized by generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and unremarkable light microscopy findings, with podocyte effacement seen on electron microscopy. It typically responds well to corticosteroids.

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hurler disease.

 

The clinical presentation described, including coarse facial features, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and copious mucus discharge from the nose, is characteristic of Hurler disease. Hurler disease is a severe form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPS 1), which results from a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, specifically heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, in various tissues.

 

Key Clinical Features of Hurler Disease:

 

  • Coarse facial features: The facial appearance is often described as "gargoyle-like" due to the thickening of facial structures.
  • Macroglossia and thick lips: Enlargement of the tongue and thickened lips are common in Hurler disease.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is a typical finding.
  • Corneal clouding: Although not mentioned in the question, this is another characteristic finding in Hurler disease.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: These include joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.
  • Upper respiratory tract involvement: Patients may experience recurrent respiratory infections, noisy breathing, and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: This is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by features such as macrosomia (large body size), macroglossia, hemihypertrophy (asymmetrical body growth), omphalocele (abdominal wall defect), and an increased risk of certain cancers like Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. However, the combination of features presented in this case aligns more closely with Hurler disease.

 

Option C. Proteus Syndrome: This is a rare condition characterized by overgrowth of bones, skin, and other tissues. It does not typically present with the features described in the question, such as coarse facies, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious mucus discharge.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: While congenital hypothyroidism can present with macroglossia and coarse facial features, it typically does not cause the combination of symptoms described in this case, such as hepatosplenomegaly and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hurler disease, a form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1, presents with coarse facial features, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious nasal discharge, and is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase leading to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: Gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GABRA-1

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), also known as Janz syndrome, is a common type of generalized epilepsy that typically manifests in adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and absence seizures. A mutation in the GABRA-1 gene, which encodes for the alpha-1 subunit of the GABA(A) receptor, has been linked to juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The GABA(A) receptor is crucial in mediating inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain, and mutations in this gene can disrupt normal neuronal function, leading to the seizures characteristic of JME.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHYNN-1: This gene is not associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The correct genes associated with JME include GABRA-1 and others like CLNC2, EFHC1, and CACNB4.

 

Option C. FMR-1: The FMR-1 gene is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which is a leading cause of inherited intellectual disability, not juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because not all the genes listed are involved in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Only GABRA-1 from the options given is directly linked to JME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The GABRA-1 gene is a key genetic factor in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ectopic ureter

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with an ectopic ureter. An ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly where the ureter does not insert into the bladder at the normal location (the trigone). Instead, it may insert outside the bladder, such as into the urethra, vagina, or other structures in females. This abnormal insertion leads to continuous dribbling of urine because the urine bypasses the bladder's normal storage function.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Continuous Urine Dribbling: The hallmark symptom of an ectopic ureter, particularly in females, is constant urinary dribbling or incontinence despite normal voiding. This is because the ureter drains urine directly into a location outside the bladder, where it cannot be stored.
  • Normal Voiding: The girl still voids normally because she likely has a second, normally positioned ureter that drains into the bladder, allowing for regular voiding alongside the continuous leakage from the ectopic ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter as it enters the bladder, which can cause obstruction and lead to urinary symptoms. However, it does not typically cause continuous dribbling.

 

Option C. Congenital megaureter: This refers to an abnormal dilation of the ureter, usually associated with some degree of obstruction or reflux, but it does not typically present with continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Option D. Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR): VUR is the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and possibly the kidneys. It can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections and renal damage but does not typically cause continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female with continuous dribbling of urine since birth, despite normal voiding, due to the abnormal insertion of the ureter outside the bladder.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

 

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are consistent with infantile spasms, which is seen in WEST Syndrome. The drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in WEST syndrome is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Drug of choice of baby with infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabtrin.

 

Infantile spasms typically present as clusters of sudden, brief, symmetric, and often flexor or extensor jerks of the limbs or trunk. The spasms are usually associated with regression of developmental milestones, including loss of acquired skills such as smiling, babbling, or sitting up. Hypsarrhythmia, which is a chaotic and disorganized pattern of high-amplitude, asynchronous spikes and slow waves on EEG, is a characteristic finding in infantile spasms.

 

ACTH is the most effective medication for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is believed to work by decreasing the inflammation and abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is thought to be responsible for the spasms. ACTH is typically administered as a daily injection, usually for a duration of several weeks. The response to treatment is usually monitored with serial EEGs, which should show improvement in the hypsarrhythmia pattern.

 

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:

 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is the second line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not typically used for treating infantile spasms associated with West Syndrome.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication but is not the first-line treatment for West Syndrome.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: Phenobarbitone is the first line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not the preferred treatment for infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

 

The most appropriate next step for a child with a VP shunt who presents with symptoms suspicious for meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from the shunt tap and/or lumbar puncture. It is important to diagnose and treat meningitis quickly in patients with VP shunts, as untreated meningitis can cause shunt malfunction and other complications.

 

The diagnosis of meningitis in a child with a VP shunt requires obtaining blood cultures and CSF samples. Blood cultures are needed to identify the causative organism, while CSF samples are used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the infection. CSF can be obtained either through a shunt tap or a lumbar puncture, depending on the child's clinical status and the availability of the appropriate resources.

 

VP shunt fluid is usually obtained from a reservoir that is easily accessible subcutaneously. After sterile preparation, the reservoir should be punctured with a 25-gauge needle. The risk of introducing infection is also low (4.1%).

 

 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt:

 

 

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CS) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

 

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following:

 

  • Infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, usually from Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Shunt over drainage (slit ventricles)
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection
  • Shunt obstruction
  • Inguinal hernia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: as the patient is showing features of complication, wait and watch will not be the appropriate answer.

 

Option B. Check shunt patency by nuclear study: we should check the patency of the shunt but as the patient is showing signs of meningitis we should do a CSF analysis by shunt tap.

 

Option C. Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture: the main source of infection is from the shunt, so taking CSF sample from there is best.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is the diagnosis in this case, which is characterized by an open, inside-out bladder on the surface of the lower abdominal wall, and an exposed dorsal urethra. The pathogenesis of this condition is thought to be due to an embryological defect in abdominal wall development. In affected females, there is epispadias with bifid clitoris and small, laterally displaced labia minora, while in affected males, there is epispadias as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrochisis: The abdominal contents will be out and not covered in a sac.

 

 

 

Option C. Superior vesical fissure: A defect of closure in the infra-umbilical abdominal wall through which vesical mucous membrane protruded. A probe introduced into the urethra appeared externally at the place of the infraumbilical defect. Following the diagnosis of superior vesical fissure, resection of the protruding vesical mucous membrane and closure were carried out.

 

Option D. Anterior ectopic anus: The above features and image doesn’t correlate with the mentioned findings in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Bladder exstrophy presents as an exposed, inside-out bladder on the abdominal wall, often associated with continuous dribbling of urine, especially in female newborns with epispadias and bifid clitoris.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

choices.text: Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 12%

 

A day-night variation of FEV1 > 12%, is not a standard measure used in the diagnosis of asthma. While diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (PEF) is often used to monitor asthma control, it is not specifically measured by FEV1, and a >12% variation in FEV1 between day and night is not typically used as a diagnostic criterion for asthma.

 

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) are essential in diagnosing and managing asthma, particularly in identifying airflow obstruction and its reversibility. Specific findings on PFTs suggestive of asthma include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation: An increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) by more than 15% after the administration of a bronchodilator like salbutamol is indicative of reversible airway obstruction, which is characteristic of asthma.

 

Option B. FEV1/FVC< 80%: A FEV1/FVC (Forced Vital Capacity) ratio of less than 80% is suggestive of obstructive lung disease, including asthma. This ratio decreases because of the increased airway resistance in asthmatic patients.

 

Option D. Decrease in FEV1>12% after exercise: A decrease in FEV1 by more than 15% after exercise is a sign of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, a common feature of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in FEV1 > 12% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perinatal transmission 

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is through perinatal transmission. Perinatal transmission, also known as vertical transmission, occurs during labor and delivery. This can happen when the newborn is exposed to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal.

 

Mechanisms of HIV Transmission in Infants:

 

  • In utero (During pregnancy): HIV can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus.
  • During delivery (Perinatal): This is the most common mode of transmission and occurs when the baby is exposed to infected blood and secretions during the birthing process.
  • After birth by breastfeeding: This is a less common mode of transmission compared to perinatal transmission but still significant, especially in regions where breastfeeding is essential for infant nutrition.

 

Risk Factors for Vertical Transmission:

 

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast milk: While breast milk can transmit HIV, it is less common compared to perinatal transmission during delivery.

 

Option C. Transplacental: HIV can be transmitted transplacentally during pregnancy, but this is not as common as perinatal transmission.

 

Option D. Exchange transfusion with infected blood: This is a rare cause of HIV infection in newborns compared to perinatal transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is perinatal transmission, occurring during labor and delivery.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

 

Based on the clinical presentation of low hemoglobin levels, the presence of target cells in the blood smear, and the need for repeated blood transfusions, the most likely diagnosis is thalassemia. Thalassemia is an inherited disorder affecting the production of alpha- or beta-globin chains, leading to an imbalance in globin chain synthesis. This imbalance results in ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, requiring frequent blood transfusions.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A genetic disorder that can be categorized into alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia based on the affected globin chain. The severity of the condition depends on the number of functioning globin genes.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive diagnosis of thalassemia is made through globin gene sequencing, which identifies mutations in the genes encoding the globin chains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): HPLC is used as a screening tool for thalassemia and other hemoglobinopathies by analyzing hemoglobin fractions. However, it is not definitive for diagnosing thalassemia.

 

Option B. Ferritin levels estimation: Ferritin levels are used to assess iron stores in the body, particularly in cases of iron deficiency anemia or iron overload. It is not diagnostic for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: While bone marrow aspiration can reveal ineffective erythropoiesis and hypercellularity, it is not used for a definitive diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Hemoglobin Patterns:

 

  • Normal Hemoglobin Pattern: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%

 

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis is another tool used for screening, often complemented by HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

 

On the fourth day, this child's bilirubin level is only 8 mg/dl, indicating physiologic jaundice. Because the child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding on a regular and exclusive basis.

 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is caused by increased bilirubin production from foetal red blood cell breakdown combined with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation by the immature neonatal liver.

 

It usually appears on the second or third day after birth, peaks on the fourth day at 5-6 mg/dL, and then drops to 2 mg/dL between the fifth and seventh days.

 

Note: Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

 

  1. Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth.
  2. Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant.
  3. Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level.
  4. Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) levels above the expected normal range -Jaundice is seen in the mid-abdomen (= 15 mg/dL) and soles (- 20 mg/dL).
  5. Total Serum Bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy.
  6. Total Serum Bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exchange transfusion: exchange transfusion is not the correct option.

 

Indications of exchange transfusion are:

 

  1. History of Direct coombs test positive
  2. Cord hemoglobin < 5gm/cl and cord bilirubin >10 mg /dl
  3. History of sibling death / erythroblastosis fetalis

 

Option B. Stop breastfeeding and start phototherapy: We don’t stop breast feeding unless the baby is a case of galactosemia or lactose intolerance because in these conditions breast feeding is contraindicated.

 

Option C. IV fluids and phototherapy: IV fluids is not the right option as the baby is feeding well. We don’t give IV fluids to a baby who is feeding well.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

choices.text: Potassium binding resins
Broad spectrum antibiotics

questions.text: A 3-week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127, K+ - 6 meq with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrocortisone

 

The neonate in this case presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia (Na+ 127 mEq/L), hyperkalemia (K+ 6 mEq/L), and hypotension (BP 50/22 mm Hg). These findings are suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. CAH is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in cortisol production, leading to an overproduction of androgens and a deficiency in aldosterone, which causes salt-wasting and hyperkalemia.

 

The treatment of choice in this situation is hydrocortisone, which replaces the deficient glucocorticoids. Hydrocortisone will help manage the adrenal insufficiency by increasing cortisol levels, thereby normalizing blood pressure, glucose levels, and reducing the overproduction of androgens. In addition to hydrocortisone, mineralocorticoid replacement with fludrocortisone may also be required to address the salt-wasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spironolactone: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is not appropriate in this scenario as it would exacerbate hyperkalemia and does not address the underlying cortisol deficiency.

 

Option B. Potassium binding resins: These are used to treat hyperkalemia by promoting the excretion of potassium in the stool. While they may reduce potassium levels, they do not address the underlying cause of the hyperkalemia, which is the deficiency in cortisol and aldosterone.

 

Option D. Broad spectrum antibiotics: Antibiotics are used to treat infections and are not relevant in managing CAH unless the patient has a concurrent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrocortisone is the first-line treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension in neonates.

questions.text:
What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder
  2. lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby
  3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby
  4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4


According to the Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines, the recommended actions for a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid are as follows:

 

4. For a non-vigorous baby (poor muscle tone, weak or absent respiratory effort, or heart rate <100 bpm): The baby should receive positive pressure ventilation (PPV) following initial resuscitation steps. The current guidelines recommend PPV over routine intratracheal suctioning in non-vigorous infants because studies have shown that routine suctioning does not improve outcomes and may delay necessary resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction of the nose and mouth before delivery of the shoulders and routine intratracheal suctioning are no longer recommended in the current guidelines.

 

Option B. 2, 4: While PPV is recommended for non-vigorous infants, routine intratracheal suctioning is not indicated.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction is not recommended under the current guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:
 

For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

 

The triad of Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) points to a diagnosis of Congenital rubella syndrome

 

Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections.

 

Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles)

 

Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Option C. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection: Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNS

 

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients. It contains 5% dextrose along with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride). This combination helps to provide both hydration and glucose, which is essential for energy. Additionally, DNS can help maintain electrolyte balance, which is critical in pediatric patients who are often at risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. In practice, 1 ml of potassium chloride (KCl) is often added to every 100 ml of DNS to ensure adequate potassium levels, which are vital for proper cellular function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RL (Ringer's Lactate): Ringer's Lactate is often used for fluid resuscitation in adults and in specific conditions such as acidosis. However, it does not contain dextrose, which is necessary for pediatric patients for energy and maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Option C. NS (Normal Saline): Normal Saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is useful for hydration and electrolyte balance but lacks dextrose. Pediatric patients need a source of glucose, especially in cases of prolonged fasting or illness, making NS alone less suitable than DNS.

 

Option D. 5% dextrose: 5% dextrose provides glucose but lacks the electrolytes found in saline. This can lead to imbalances, particularly in pediatric patients, where maintaining proper electrolyte levels is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal-recessive disorder

 

The pedigree chart shown suggests an autosomal-recessive disorder based on several key observations:

 

  1. Horizontal Pattern: The affected individuals appear in the same generation but are not present in the preceding or subsequent generations. This pattern is characteristic of autosomal-recessive inheritance, where the disorder tends to skip generations unless both parents carry the recessive allele.
  2. Unaffected Parents: Both parents of affected individuals are unaffected, suggesting they are carriers of the recessive allele. In autosomal-recessive inheritance, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to express the disorder.
  3. Carrier Frequency: According to autosomal-recessive inheritance patterns, when both parents are carriers, there is a 25% chance that their offspring will have the disorder (inherit two mutated genes), a 50% chance that the offspring will be carriers (inherit one mutated gene and one normal gene), and a 25% chance that the offspring will have a normal genotype (inherit two normal genes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal-dominant disorder: This pattern typically shows affected individuals in every generation, with both males and females equally likely to inherit the disorder. Affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to their offspring, regardless of the other parent's genotype.

 

Option B. X-linked dominant disorder: This pattern would show affected females more frequently if the father is affected and can appear in every generation. However, affected males would pass the condition to all of their daughters and none of their sons.

 

Option D. X-linked recessive disorder: This pattern is more common in males, as they only have one X chromosome. Carrier females would pass the disorder to 50% of their sons, and 50% of their daughters would be carriers. However, in this pedigree, both males and females are affected equally, and the pattern does not suggest an X-linked inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal-recessive disorders are typically characterized by a horizontal pattern of inheritance, where the disorder appears in siblings of the same generation but may skip generations, with unaffected parents often being carriers.

choices.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

The clinical vignette and images provided suggest HFMD meningitis.

 

The presence of vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, as well as images of the lesions, suggest Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD). The presence of neck stiffness, as well as CSF with normal glucose levels, elevated lymphocytes, and protein levels, suggests viral meningitis.

 

Therefore the best answer is - Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:

 

Causes:

 

  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 which is a subgroup of enteroviruses.
  • In large outbreaks, other enteroviruses like enterovirus71, coxsackie A viruses 5,6,7,9, 10 and coxsackie B virus 2 and 5 may also cause HFMD.

 

Clinical features: HFMD is often a minor condition.

 

  • The tongue, posterior pharynx, buccal mucosa, palate, lips, etc. may all have vesicular lesions.
  • Lesions that are maculopapular, vesicular, or pustular may appear on the hands, fingers, buttocks, or groin.
  • Compared to the feet, lesions are more frequently found on the hands.
  • These vesicles disappear within a week.
  • Enterovirus 71 infections are more serious and are linked to cardiovascular and neurological symptoms.
  • Complications from coxsackievirus A16 infections might occasionally include shock, encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and myocarditis.
  • A severe variant of HFMD called atypical HFMD is caused by coxsackievirus A6.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • HFMD is usually diagnosed clinically by the characteristic lesions.
  • Viral culture can be done to confirm the presence of enterovirus. Blood, CSF, urine, and mucosal swabs can be cultured.
  • RT-PCR testing to detect the viral genome is more sensitive and specific.
  • PCR testing of CSF in children with meningitis is frequently positive even when the cultures are negative.

 

Treatment:

 

  • No specific antiviral agent is proven to be effective against enteroviruses. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Milrinone is suggested as an effective agent for enterovirus 71 cardiopulmonary disease.
  • Immunoglobulins have been used to manage severe cases but with varying outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis with sepsis: Bacterial meningitis with sepsis is not a likely differential diagnosis for vesicular lesions with this distribution. HSV encephalitis manifests with typical findings of injury to the frontal or parietal cortex or limbic system, including anosmia, memory loss, focal seizures, expressive aphasia, and peculiar behaviour.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex gingivostomatitis and meningoencephalitis: Despite having vesicular lesions, meningoencephalitis and herpes simplex gingivostomatitis show differently clinically. High-grade fever, rapid onset of excruciating mouth pain, and saliva dribbling are the symptoms of HSV gingivostomatitis.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Tuberculous meningitis is improbable given the absence of a history of exposure to TB. CSF results in bacterial meningitis often include reduced glucose and raised neutrophils and protein levels. In most cases, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose and high amount

 

The majority of the time, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose levels, increased lymphocytes, and protein levels.

 

  • Other possible differentials for vesicular lesions include hand-foot-and-mouth disease, varicella (chickenpox), and herpangina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest indicator of pathological gastroesophageal reflux in infants (GERD)? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Respiratory symptoms

 

Explanation:

 

Recurrent respiratory symptoms such as wheezing, stridor, chronic cough, and apnea are the earliest indicators of pathological gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) in infants. These symptoms arise due to the aspiration of gastric contents, which irritates the airways. GERD can lead to complications like failure to thrive and recurrent pulmonary issues. While postprandial regurgitation is common in infants, it does not necessarily indicate pathological reflux unless accompanied by other symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postprandial regurgitation: This is a common symptom of physiological reflux and does not alone indicate GERD.

 

Option C. Upper GI bleed: This is a more specific but less common indicator of severe esophagitis due to GERD.

 

Option D. Esophageal stricture: This is a late complication of untreated GERD and not an early indicator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent respiratory symptoms are the earliest indicators of pathological gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) in infants.

questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-24 months

 

  • Children attain half of their adult height by the age of 20-24 months.
  • For children under 2 years of age, length is measured with the help of  an infantometer or rigid measuring table. The infant's head is held firmly against a fixed upright headboard, legs are straightened, and feet are at right angles to legs with toes pointing upwards. The length of the baby is measured from a scale set in the measuring table.
  • Measuring the length of a child lying on a mattress or using cloth tapes is inaccurate and not recommended.
  • Height is measured by asking the child to stand upright with heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and back of the head in contact with a vertical surface such as a wall, height measuring rod, or a stadiometer. The child should look directly forward, and the headpiece is kept firmly over the head to compress the hair.

 

The growth and development of a child between the age of 18 - 24 months can be classified as,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children typically attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months, a critical milestone in early childhood growth and development.

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is a crucial tool used in neonatal screening for detecting inborn errors of metabolism. This test involves taking a small blood sample from the infant's heel, which is then dried on a filter paper and sent for analysis. Tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) is the primary technique used to analyze the sample for a wide range of metabolic disorders, such as phenylketonuria (PKU), maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), and others. Early detection through DBS testing allows for prompt diagnosis and treatment, significantly improving the prognosis for affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood grouping: Blood grouping in neonates is typically done in cases of suspected neonatal jaundice to rule out Rh or ABO incompatibility, not using DBS testing.

 

Option C. Bilirubin testing: Bilirubin levels are tested to evaluate jaundice in neonates, particularly in cases of Rh or ABO incompatibility or breastfeeding-related jaundice, but this is not done using DBS.

 

Option D. Coombs Test: The Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that may cause hemolysis in conditions like hemolytic disease of the newborn. It is not performed using dried blood spots.

 

Educational Objective:


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

choices.text: 90 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
80 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
100 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

questions.text: Which of the following fits into the criteria of severe variable deceleration, variations less than: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds.

 

Severe variable decelerations in fetal heart rate (FHR) are characterized by a significant reduction in the heart rate below the baseline. The specific criterion for a severe variable deceleration is when the heart rate drops below 70 beats per minute and this reduction persists for at least 60 seconds.

 

Variable decelerations are sudden decreases in the FHR that occur with or without contractions. They are commonly caused by umbilical cord compression, which impedes blood flow through the umbilical vein and arteries, leading to a reduction in fetal cardiac output. This type of deceleration is defined by a decrease of at least 15 beats per minute below the baseline and typically lasts between 15 seconds and less than 2 minutes.

 

Classification of Variable Decelerations:

 

  • Mild: Heart rate decreases to greater than 80 beats per minute regardless of duration, or decelerations lasting less than 30 seconds regardless of the heart rate, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting less than 60 seconds.
  • Moderate: Heart rate decreases to more than 70 beats per minute for 30-60 seconds, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting more than 60 seconds.
  • Severe: Heart rate decreases to less than 70 beats per minute for an extended duration (at least 60 seconds).

 

(70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds) meets the criteria for severe variable deceleration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe variable decelerations are defined by a fetal heart rate dropping to less than 70 beats per minute for at least 60 seconds, typically due to umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as developmental delay? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding by spoon


Feeding with a spoon is a social milestone that typically develops around 18 months of age. If a child is unable to feed themselves with a spoon by 24 months, it can be considered a developmental delay. By the age of 3 years, most children should have well-established self-feeding skills, including the ability to hold and use a spoon effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one leg: This milestone typically develops around 4 years of age. It would not be considered a delay if a 3-year-old is unable to hop on one leg.

 

Option B. Drawing a square: Drawing a square is a fine motor skill that generally develops around 4 and a half years of age, so its absence at 3 years old is not considered a delay.

 

Option D. Passing a ball to someone: This social and motor skill usually develops around 4 years of age. Therefore, a 3-year-old not being able to pass a ball would not be considered delayed.

 

Educational Objective:


The absence of feeding with a spoon by 24 months can indicate a developmental delay in social and motor skills in a child.

questions.text:
How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Airway and breathing
  2. IV Lorazepam
  3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone
  4. IV Fosphenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness.

 

Status epilepticus is a neurological emergency defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness between episodes. Prompt and systematic management is essential to prevent long-term neurological damage or death.

 

Management Sequence:

 

1. Airway and Breathing: The first priority is to ensure that the airway is open and that the child is breathing adequately. This may involve positioning the child, providing oxygen, and, if necessary, securing the airway with advanced airway management techniques.

 

2. IV Lorazepam: Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the first-line treatment for status epilepticus due to their rapid onset of action and effectiveness in terminating seizures. Lorazepam is typically administered intravenously.

 

4. IV Fosphenytoin: If seizures continue after the administration of a benzodiazepine, IV fosphenytoin (or phenytoin) is used as a second-line agent. It helps to stabilize neuronal membranes and prevent further seizure activity.

 

3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone: These agents are used if seizures persist despite initial treatments. Midazolam can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously, while propofol and thiopentone are typically reserved for refractory status epilepticus and may require the child to be in an intensive care setting due to the need for mechanical ventilation and close monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of status epilepticus in children should follow a systematic approach: securing the airway and ensuring breathing, administering a benzodiazepine, followed by fosphenytoin if seizures persist, and considering more potent agents like midazolam, propofol, or thiopentone if the status epilepticus is refractory to initial treatments.

questions.text: An infant of a diabetic mother with a birth weight of 3.8 kg presents with seizures 16 hours after birth. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2014 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypoglycemia

 

Explanation:

 

Neonatal hypoglycemia is a common cause of seizures in infants of diabetic mothers. These infants are at increased risk of hypoglycemia due to maternal hyperglycemia leading to fetal hyperinsulinemia. When the maternal glucose supply is removed at birth, the high insulin levels can cause a rapid drop in the infant's blood glucose. Hypoglycemia can present with symptoms such as jitteriness, lethargy, and seizures. Although hypocalcemia can also cause seizures in these infants, hypoglycemia is more common within the first 24 hours of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypocalcemia: While a possible cause, it is less common than hypoglycemia as an initial cause of seizures in infants of diabetic mothers.

 

Option C. Birth asphyxia: This can cause neonatal seizures but is less likely in the context of an otherwise stable infant with a specific maternal history.

 

Option D. Intraventricular hemorrhage: This is a potential cause of neonatal seizures but less likely compared to hypoglycemia in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoglycemia is the most likely cause of seizures in an infant of a diabetic mother presenting within the first 24 hours of life.

questions.text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chorioretinitis

 

  • The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis.
  • Congenital toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii that occurs when a pregnant woman becomes infected and passes the infection on to her developing fetus. The severity of the infection can vary depending on the timing of the infection during pregnancy and the degree of immune response mounted by the fetus.
  • It is acquired perorally from ingesting food that contains oocysts; transplacentally, during vaginal delivery; or rarely, parenterally.
  • Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, occurring in up to 80% of affected infants. It is a type of eye inflammation that affects the retina and can lead to vision impairment or blindness if left untreated.
  • Other common manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include hydrocephalus (accumulation of fluid in the brain), hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), but these are less common than chorioretinitis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocephalus: Accumulation of fluid in the brain can occur in congenital toxoplasmosis but is less common than chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is another possible manifestation but not as common as chorioretinitis.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Low platelet count can occur but is less common compared to chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, affecting up to 80% of infected infants and potentially leading to vision impairment or blindness.

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

 

  • Children with thalassemia who undergo multiple blood transfusions are at risk of iron overload, which can cause significant damage to organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.
  • Monitoring liver iron concentration is the best method to assess iron overload in such children, as it is an indicator of total body iron stores.
  • Liver iron concentration can be measured invasively using a liver biopsy or non-invasively using T2 MRI of the liver. The latter is preferred due to its non-invasiveness.
  • Treatment for iron overload in thalassemia patients typically involves the use of chelation therapy, which helps to remove excess iron from the body. Deferoxamine is typically given through intravenous or subcutaneous infusion, while deferasirox and deferiprone can be given orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI T2 myocardium: Quantitative iron overload in the heart is determined using a T2 MRI of the myocardium. However, it can be done sooner if there are symptoms of severe iron overload. It is often performed in children older than 10 years. If the patient's transfusion and chelation histories are unknown, it can still be done.

 

Option C. Serum ferritin: Although serum ferritin is elevated, other inflammatory disorders also cause it to be elevated, making it a less sensitive marker.

 

Option D. NTBI (Non-transferrin-bound iron): Iron in plasma is typically bound to cccc. However, when there is an excess of iron, it is unable to bind to transferrin, which results in the formation of non-transferrin-bound iron. (NTBI). It may serve as a marker for iron excess, however albumin, citrate, and uric acid in the plasma all have an impact. As a result, it cannot be utilized as a tool to quantify iron overload and serve as a guide for designing chelation therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  2. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  3. Cotrimoxazole is not given.
  4. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

It is true that bowel and bladder dysfunction increase the incidence of recurrence of UTI in children, and that children who experience a recurrence of UTI undergo a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: A newborn is presenting with history of continuous drooling of saliva and frothiness in mouth, it is also associated with respiratory distress, the X ray of the child reveals the following image, what will be probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tracheoesophageal fistula

 

The current clinical situation points to a tracheoesophageal fistula. An X-ray revealing a nasogastric (NG) tube in the proximal esophagus and a stomach bloated with gas are suggestive of esophageal atresia given the symptoms of frothiness and respiratory distress.

 

An improper connection between the esophagus and the trachea is known as a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is often divided into five categories, which are as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transient tachypnea of newborn: Important points are: term baby born through cesarian section with tachypnea which gets settled by itself by 48-72 hours.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic eversion: Diaphragm eventration is the permanent elevation of a hemidiaphragm and can be due to congenital or acquired causes. Diaphragm eventration can become a serious condition resulting in severe respiratory distress and death if left untreated.

 

Option D. Hyaline membrane disease: Baby should be a preterm with severe distress with x ray showing white out lung.

 

Educational Objective:


A newborn with continuous drooling, frothiness in the mouth, and respiratory distress, along with an X-ray showing a coiled NG tube and gas in the stomach, is likely to have a tracheoesophageal fistula.

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 years

 

At age of 3 years, handedness is seen. The child may become frustrated if attempts are made in changing the hand preference.

 

Other milestones reached at 3 years-

 

  • Rides tricycle
  • Alternate feet going upstairs
  • Builds a tower of 9 blocks
  • Copies a circle
  • Knows full name and gender

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: Standing without support comes by 1 year

 

Option B. 2 years: A child has vocab of 100 words by 2 years

 

Option D. 4 years: A child can tell poem & stories by 4 years

 

Educational Objective:

 

At the age of 3 years, handedness is seen.

choices.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics
Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

 

In the given clinical scenario, it is important to establish or rule out a diagnosis of HIV infection before evaluating for secondary infections. Therefore, the next best step is to obtain a dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR. AIDS enteropathy, a syndrome of malabsorption with partial villous atrophy not associated with a specific pathogen, has been postulated to be a result of direct HIV infection of the gut.

 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in infants born to HIV-infected mothers is done using various methods, including HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program now uses an HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

 

Infants born to HIV-positive mothers should be exclusively breastfed or fed with replacement feeds exclusively until 6 months of age. Infants should also receive AR prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine.

 

It is common for HIV-infected infants to experience gastrointestinal tract involvement, with bacteria (Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella, Mycobacterium avium complex), protozoa (Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Isospora, microsporidia), viruses (CMV, HSV, rotavirus), and fungi (Candida) being common pathogens. MAC and protozoal infections tend to be the most severe and prolonged in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Test stool for giardiasis and give antibiotics: This is not the preferred immediate next step. First, the diagnosis of HIV infection should be established before treating secondary infections.

 

Option C. Antibody tests for HIV: Antibody tests for HIV are not useful in establishing the diagnosis of HIV infection in infants. This is because all infants born to HIV-infected mothers test antibodies positive at birth due to the passive transfer of maternal HIV antibodies across the placenta. It can be used as a diagnostic tool after 18 months of age.

 

Option D. Aerobic culture: Aerobic culture is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection. It is more relevant for identifying bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

questions.text: What is the mid arm circumference for severe acute malnutrition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11.5 cm

 

A mid-arm circumference of less than 11.5 cm is often used as one of the anthropometric indicators for severe acute malnutrition in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition is defined as

 

  1. Weight for height <-3 standard deviation
  2. Mid upper arm circumference <11.5cm
  3. Bilateral pedal edema

questions.text: What is the karyotype associated with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 47, XY (+21)


The image shows a single palmar crease, also known as a "simian crease," which is commonly associated with Down syndrome. Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra chromosome 21, resulting in the karyotype 47, XY (+21) in males or 47, XX (+21) in females. This condition leads to a variety of physical and intellectual disabilities, and the single palmar crease is one of the characteristic physical findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 45, XO: This karyotype represents Turner syndrome, a condition where a female has only one X chromosome. It is not associated with a single palmar crease.

 

Option C. 47, XY (+18): This karyotype is associated with Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18. Edward syndrome has a different set of physical characteristics, such as clenched fists with overlapping fingers and rocker-bottom feet, rather than a single palmar crease.

 

Option D. 47, XY (+13): This karyotype corresponds to Patau syndrome, or trisomy 13, which is associated with severe congenital anomalies including cleft lip/palate and polydactyly, not a single palmar crease.

 

Educational Objective:


Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common non-preventable cause of intellectual disability and is associated with characteristic physical findings such as a single palmar crease.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age less than -2SD: This defines moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), not severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

 

Option B. Weight for height less than +2SD: This would indicate overnutrition or obesity, not malnutrition.

 

Option C. Weight for age less than +3SD: This is not relevant to malnutrition and could indicate overnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

 

Dehydration in children is classified based on clinical signs into mild (some dehydration) and severe dehydration. The symptoms of severe dehydration are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and urgency of care.

 

"Thirsty child," is typically associated with some dehydration rather than severe dehydration. A thirsty child is likely still alert and responsive, seeking fluids, which suggests that dehydration is present but not yet severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drowsy child: Indicates severe dehydration where the child’s mental status is altered, often due to inadequate perfusion to the brain.

 

Option B. Skin pinch retracts slowly: This is a reliable sign of severe dehydration and indicates significant fluid loss.

 

Option D. Sunken fontanelle: Especially in infants, a sunken fontanelle is a common and concerning sign of severe dehydration, indicating decreased intracranial pressure due to fluid loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text: The following device shown attached to the baby is used in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Measure central cyanosis.

 

The device shown in the image is a pulse oximeter. A pulse oximeter is commonly used to measure the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of the blood and monitor heart rate. While it is useful in many clinical settings, including neonatal care, it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

 

Cyanosis is a clinical sign that appears when there is at least 5 g/dL of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood. A pulse oximeter measures oxygen saturation but does not directly assess the color changes in the skin or mucous membranes, which are crucial for identifying cyanosis. Moreover, in conditions like severe anemia, a patient might have a low oxygen saturation without appearing cyanosed.

 

However, measuring central cyanosis requires clinical observation and is not reliably detected by a pulse oximeter. Therefore, a pulse oximeter is not used to measure central cyanosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Uses of a Pulse Oximeter:

 

Option A. In CPR: Pulse oximeters are used to monitor oxygenation and the effectiveness of chest compressions and ventilation during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

 

Option B. To know about apnea: Pulse oximeters can indicate apnea by detecting bradycardia and desaturation episodes.

 

Option C. In neonatal resuscitation: Pulse oximeters are vital for assessing the newborn's oxygenation status during resuscitation and adjusting oxygen therapy as needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pulse oximeter is useful in various neonatal and resuscitation settings to monitor oxygen saturation and heart rate, but it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

The chloride level of sweat is evaluated in cystic fibrosis.

 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Mutation in chromosome no. 7
  • Primary defect: CFTR gene [Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene on chromosome 7q31.2]
  • Other defects: Chloride channels, Potassium channels, Epithelial sodium channels

 

 

  • Sweat ducts normally absorb sodium from lumen which decreases in CF causing salty sweat.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat is there. Other ducts are obstructed.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

Hallmark of cystic fibrosis –

 

High sodium and chloride levels Sweat chloride level is >60mEq/L in 2 occasions Airways, pancreas & GIT - Normally sodium uptake is there from luminal fluid but in CF there is increase of sodium and water uptake from lumen causing thick, viscid secretions.

 

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria occurs due to absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme, leading to phenylketonuria. Diagnosis is made by Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of the tissue enzyme glucocerebrosidase that splits glucose from glucosylceramide, resulting in accumulation of the latter in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. Diagnosis is made by measuring glucocerebrosidase levels in leukocytes or skin fibroblasts. Serum chitotriosidase levels are elevated.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta causes defective type-1 collagen. Presents with a triad of blue sclera, Fragile bones, Early deafness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

choices.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

 

Hutchinson's triad refers to:

 

  1. Interstitial keratitis
  2. 8th nerve deafness
  3. Hutchinson incisors

 

Commonly seen in late congenital syphilis.

 

 

Features of Hutchinson Teeth:

 

  • Peg-shaped with a crescent-shaped notch
  • Thinning or discoloration of enamel
  • Smaller teeth
  • Widely spaced teeth

 

Mulberry molars:

 

Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are also seen in Congenital Syphilis. They are multicuspid first molars in which the tooth's grinding surface, which is narrower than that at the gingival margin, has many small cusps instead of the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars: Mulberry molars are also seen in congenital syphilis but are not part of Hutchinson's triad. Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are first molars with a narrower grinding surface and multiple small cusps rather than the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

Option B. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars: The correct dental component of Hutchinson's triad is Hutchinson incisors, not molars.

 

Option C. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors: The term "mulberry incisors" is not accurate; Hutchinson incisors are the correct term, which refers to the characteristic dental deformity in Hutchinson's triad.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hutchinson's triad consists of interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors, and it is a diagnostic feature of late congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt without a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/ L, majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a CSF glucose level of 70 mg dL & blood glucose level - 300 mg dL). How will you manage the index case? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vancomycin + ceftriaxone

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory results provided strongly suggest a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. The CSF analysis shows significant findings including a high WBC count predominantly composed of neutrophils, elevated protein, and a relatively low CSF glucose level considering the elevated blood glucose. The CSF glucose level, when compared to the blood glucose, gives a ratio that is suggestive of bacterial meningitis (a ratio of 0.4 or less is highly indicative).

 

Meningitis can present with symptoms such as high-grade fever, altered consciousness, neck rigidity, and positive meningeal signs like Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs. The diagnosis is confirmed by CSF analysis, which typically shows:

 

  • Neutrophilic pleocytosis
  • Increased protein levels
  • Decreased glucose concentrations
  • Presence of microorganisms on Gram stain and culture

 

The initial treatment of bacterial meningitis should include broad-spectrum antibiotics that cover the most common pathogens. A combination of a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone and vancomycin is recommended to cover for Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Piperacillin + tazobactam: Piperacillin + tazobactam is used in certain situations such as hospital-acquired infections or when there is no response to ceftriaxone. However, it is not the first-line treatment for community-acquired bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin + flucytosine: Amphotericin + flucytosine are antifungal agents used to treat fungal meningitis, not bacterial meningitis. Fungal meningitis presents differently and typically in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Antitubercular therapy: Antitubercular therapy is considered when the CSF profile shows low glucose, high protein, and lymphocytic predominance, which is typical for tuberculous meningitis. The provided CSF findings do not match those of tuberculous meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin combined with a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone is the recommended initial treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliverdin 

 

Meconium is a dark and sticky substance that is normally present in a newborn's intestine at birth and is excreted in the feces after birth. It is first detected in the ileum at around 70-85 days of fetal life and fills the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of meconium is due to bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, mainly biliverdin, which is formed from the oxidation of bilirubin.

 

  • Biliverdin is responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in newborns. Biliverdin production starts later in gestation or closer to delivery, perhaps due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.
  • Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.
  • Meconium itself is the first stool of the baby, which contains biliverdin, giving it the greenish-black color.
  • Gut flora: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Option C. Meconium: Meconium is the substance itself, not the cause of its greenish-black color. The color is due to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Gut flora of neonate: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.
