questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. It consists of five components: cyanosis, retractions, grunting, air entry, and respiratory rate (RR). Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total possible score of 10. Here's the breakdown for the given case:

 

 

Summing up the scores:


1 (cyanosis) + 1 (retractions) + 2 (grunting) + 2 (air entry) + 0 (RR) = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aqueductal stenosis

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly (enlargement of ventricles of the brain) in newborns. It is a congenital condition where there is narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a small channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. This obstruction can result in an enlargement of the ventricles, which can lead to hydrocephalus (accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain). Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker syndrome, and arachnoid villi malformation are other conditions that can cause ventriculomegaly, but they are less common causes than aqueductal stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arnold chiari malformation: Arnold chiari malformation will have downward displacement of cerebellum and brainstem. This is not the most commonest cause of ventriculomegaly

 

Option B. Dandy walker malformation: Dandy walker malformation will have cerebellar hypoplasia with hydrocephalus.

 

Option C. Arachnoid villi malformation: Arachnoid villi malformation is not the most commonest cause

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the leading cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns due to the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with an olive-shaped mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyloric stenosis

 

Pyloric stenosis is a condition commonly seen in infants where there is hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to a narrowing of the pyloric canal. This condition presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding, typically around the age of 3 to 6 weeks. The physical finding of an "olive-shaped" mass in the abdomen is characteristic of this condition, which represents the enlarged pyloric muscle.

 

The X-ray findings in pyloric stenosis often show a single bubble sign due to gastric distension without further passage of air into the intestines. This is because the pyloric canal is obstructed, preventing stomach contents from moving into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: This term is more general and can refer to various types of obstructions within the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of an infant with projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped mass, this is not specific enough and does not pinpoint the pyloric obstruction characteristic of pyloric stenosis.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is characterized by a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, which is not present in this case. This condition leads to bilious vomiting due to a congenital closure or absence of the duodenal lumen, distinguishing it from pyloric stenosis, which presents with non-bilious vomiting.

 

 

Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia would show a "triple bubble" sign on imaging, which indicates obstruction beyond the duodenum in the jejunum. This would also present with bilious vomiting, unlike the non-bilious vomiting seen in pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile non-bilious vomiting, the presence of an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and a single bubble sign on X-ray. It is due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text: A 1-day old neonate presented with scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress and mediastinal shift. All of the following can be done except? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation

 

Bag and mask ventilation can be challenging and less effective in the presence of a scaphoid abdomen and mediastinal shift. In such cases, positive pressure ventilation through an endotracheal tube or a ventilator may be more appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. O2 by mask: This is a valid intervention. Providing oxygen by mask can be an initial step to improve oxygenation in a neonate with respiratory distress. The goal is to support oxygenation until more definitive measures can be taken.

 

Option B. Positive pressure ventilation by ventilator: This is a valid intervention. Positive pressure ventilation with a ventilator may be necessary in cases of severe respiratory distress or failure. It helps to provide adequate oxygenation and ventilation to the neonate.

 

Option C. ET intubation: This is a valid intervention. Endotracheal (ET) intubation may be indicated in cases where positive pressure ventilation is required or to secure the airway in the presence of respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical signs of diaphragmatic hernia, such as a scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, and mediastinal shift. Understand the appropriate interventions, including oxygen administration, positive pressure ventilation, endotracheal intubation, and the limitations of bag and mask ventilation in specific clinical scenarios.

choices.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.
Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask.

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine in a neonate during resuscitation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/ minutes despite effective compression and ventilation.

 

If the heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation, consider administering epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation.

 

 

Note: Umbilical venous catheter is the preferred method of obtaining emergency vascular access in the delivery room.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.: if the heart rate is <100 bpm, we do bag and mask ventilation.

 

Option C. Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.: If the heart rate doesnot improve after 30 seconds of bag and mask ventilation, then we do ventilation corrective steps.

 

Option D. Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask: if the baby is not responding to bag and mask ventilation then check the heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epinephrine is administered in neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective positive-pressure ventilation and chest compressions.

questions.text: A child presented with intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a “crumpled paper appearance.” What is your best diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The Ans. is Glucocerebrosidase, which is associated with Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within macrophages, resulting in cells that have a characteristic "crumpled paper" appearance when viewed under a microscope. The presence of these cells, along with symptoms like intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GALT enzyme: This enzyme is related to Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism. It does not present with a "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow biopsies, nor is it associated with the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Pompe disease: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder due to a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase. It typically involves muscle weakness and cardiomegaly but does not produce the "crumpled paper" cells seen in bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: This is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it is due to sphingomyelinase deficiency. The characteristic cells in Niemann-Pick disease have a "foamy" appearance, not the "crumpled paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow cells is a hallmark of Gaucher disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age > 10 years

 

Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.

 

Leukocyte count <50,000/mm, hyperdiploidy, trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, 17 indicate a better prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), prognostic factors such as age greater than 10 years, WBC count greater than 200,000/mm^3, male gender, presence of CNS involvement, and certain cytogenetic abnormalities such as t(9;22) or t(4;11) are associated with a poorer prognosis compared to their counterparts.

questions.text: A newborn baby came with complaints of hepatitis and cataract, lethargy & hypotonia. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely to be responsible for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The newborn presents with symptoms of hepatitis, cataract, lethargy, and hypotonia, which are indicative of a metabolic disorder involving galactose metabolism. The condition described here is galactosemia, specifically due to a deficiency in the enzyme Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).

 

Galactosemia is characterized by the inability to convert galactose into glucose. This metabolic block leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, causing damage. The primary symptoms include:

 

  • Hepatitis: Liver damage due to the accumulation of toxic substances.
  • Cataract: Formation of oil drop cataracts in the lens of the eye due to galactose accumulation.
  • Lethargy and Hypotonia: Due to the overall metabolic derangement and hypoglycemia.

 

Metabolic pathway Galactose:

 

 

The key enzymes involved include Galactokinase and Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase. In classical galactosemia, the deficiency of the GALT enzyme leads to the clinical manifestations described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to a milder form of galactosemia, primarily causing cataracts but not the full spectrum of symptoms like hepatitis and hypotonia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Uridyl glucuronyl transferase: This enzyme is related to bilirubin metabolism and is implicated in neonatal jaundice, not in the metabolism of galactose. Hence, its deficiency does not match the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactosemia due to Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency presents with hepatitis, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia, and is a contraindication for breastfeeding.

questions.text: Anenecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in which week of gestation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4th week

 

The neural tube closes by the end of the fourth week of gestation. Anencephaly occurs when the neural tube fails to close properly during this critical period.

 

Anencephaly is a serious birth defect in which a baby is born without parts of the brain and skull. It occurs when the upper part of the neural tube fails to close. The neural tube is the structure in a developing embryo that eventually becomes the baby's brain, spinal cord, and surrounding tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ananecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in 4th week of gestation.

choices.text: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the hospital with an episode of acute cholecystitis. Symptoms are controlled with medical management. On ultrasound, there is a solitary gallstone of 1.5 cm. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list

 

Explanation:

 

For acute cholecystitis that has responded to medical management, the current best practice is early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission. The Tokyo guidelines recommend early cholecystectomy within 5-7 days for mild cases (Tokyo I). For this 45-year-old patient whose symptoms are controlled with medical management, proceeding with laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list (during the same admission) is the optimal approach, as it reduces the risk of recurrent attacks while operating when inflammation has started to resolve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation and regular follow-up - This is inappropriate for a patient who has already experienced acute cholecystitis. Once symptomatic complications occur, definitive surgical management is required to prevent recurrent attacks, which can be more severe and lead to additional complications.

 

Option B. Elective cholecystectomy after inflammation subsides - This approach represents delayed surgery scheduled weeks to months after discharge, which is now considered an outdated practice. It increases the risk of recurrent episodes during the waiting period and can lead to more difficult surgery due to scarring and adhesions.

 

Option D. Urgent open cholecystectomy - Open cholecystectomy is not the first-line approach unless laparoscopic surgery is contraindicated. For mild to moderate cases that have been medically stabilized, there is no indication for urgent open surgery, as laparoscopic approach offers less postoperative pain, shorter hospital stays, and faster recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For acute cholecystitis responsive to medical management, early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission (on the next available list) is the standard of care, offering the best balance between allowing initial inflammation to subside while preventing recurrent attacks.

questions.text: Which of the following positions of the appendix is likely to present with suprapubic pain in a patient with acute appendicitis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Subcaecal

 

Explanation:

 

The subcaecal position is most likely to cause suprapubic pain among the given options. When the appendix is positioned below the cecum, it can extend inferiorly toward the pelvic brim. Inflammation in this position may spread downward, causing irritation to pelvic structures and resulting in suprapubic discomfort. This anatomical relationship explains why subcaecal appendicitis can present with symptoms similar to pelvic appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pre-ileal - When the appendix is anterior to the terminal ileum, it typically presents with classic right iliac fossa pain at McBurney's point, not suprapubic discomfort.

 

Option B. Post-ileal - Post-ileal appendicitis typically causes ill-defined tenderness immediately to the right of the umbilicus and may present with features of diarrhea and retching rather than suprapubic pain.

 

Option D. Retrocecal - The most common position (74%), retrocecal appendicitis typically causes deep tenderness in the loin with possible psoas irritation, manifesting as flank or back pain rather than suprapubic discomfort.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The anatomical positioning of a subcaecal appendix allows for extension toward the pelvic region, making it most likely among the given options to cause suprapubic symptoms when inflamed.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: What is the fluid requirement in a 3-days old baby with a birth weight of 1300 grams? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 120-130 ml/kg/day

 

The fluid requirement for a 3-days old baby weighing less than 1500 grams, such as a baby with a birth weight of 1300 grams, is 120-130 ml/kg/day. This is based on NICU protocols that specify fluid needs according to the day of life and the birth weight of the neonate. At day 3 of life, the recommended fluid intake increases from the previous days to ensure adequate hydration and metabolic support for preterm neonates.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 80-90 ml/kg/day: This fluid requirement is appropriate for the first day of life for preterm neonates with a birth weight of less than 1500 grams, not for the third day.

 

Option B. 100-110 ml/kg/day: This range is suitable for the second day of life for preterm neonates with a birth weight of less than 1500 grams, not for the third day.

 

Option D. 130-150 ml/kg/day: This fluid requirement is higher than the recommended range for a 3-day-old baby weighing 1300 grams. This range is appropriate for the fourth day of life or beyond for preterm neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 3-day-old preterm baby weighing less than 1500 grams, the fluid requirement is 120-130 ml/kg/day. This ensures proper hydration and metabolic support during this critical period.

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

The developmental milestones are correctly matched as given in option B -1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c.

 

Transfers objects - 6 to 7 months

 

Social smile - 1 to 2 months

 

Pincer grasp - 9 to 12 months

 

Walks 1-2 steps - 12 to 15 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memorize the typical age ranges for key developmental milestones in infants, such as transferring objects, social smiling, pincer grasp, and walking.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with palpable purpura, arthritis, and abdominal pain. A diagnosis of IgA vasculitis was made. What is the indication for starting steroids in Henoch Schonlein Purpura?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G.I symptoms

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes. The classic tetrad of symptoms includes palpable purpura (typically on the lower limbs), arthritis, abdominal pain, and hematuria. While the condition is generally self-limiting and resolves within 4-6 weeks, the presence of gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms such as severe abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception warrants the use of steroids. Steroids help reduce inflammation and alleviate the associated GI symptoms, providing significant relief to the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable purpura: Palpable purpura is a common manifestation of HSP, but it does not necessitate steroid treatment. The rash usually resolves on its own without the need for steroids.

 

Option B. Arthritis: While arthritis can cause discomfort and joint pain in HSP, it is typically managed with supportive care and does not require steroids. The arthritis associated with HSP is usually transient and self-limiting.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because GI symptoms are a clear indication for the use of steroids in HSP to reduce severe pain and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), steroids are indicated for the management of gastrointestinal symptoms such as severe abdominal pain or bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

Explanation:

 

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of viral meningoencephalitis in children. These viruses are a leading cause of viral infections affecting the central nervous system, particularly in children. They typically cause a range of symptoms from mild febrile illness to severe meningoencephalitis. While other viruses like mumps, arboviruses, and HSV can also cause meningoencephalitis, enteroviruses are the most frequently identified causative agents in pediatric cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mumps: While it can cause meningoencephalitis, it is less common than enterovirus.

 

Option B. Arbovirus: These viruses are important causes of epidemic encephalitis but are not the most common in children.

 

Option C. HSV: Herpes simplex virus is a significant cause of sporadic encephalitis but not the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.
